page.title: 09Sea and shore in Evie
page.content: Very few boats now fish around this coast but those that do catch{Lythe} and{Ling}which are then dried. Boats drop lobster creels, which are knitted locally, but{Lobsters}are scarce and{ {Partans}(edible crabs) usually fill the creels. Rock fishing catches{ {Sillock, Cuithe,}and{Saithe}(3 stages of Coal fish). A few people lay long lines with 50 hooks, baited with lugworm, on the beach at low tide; the incoming tide brings{Flounders, Plaice and occasionally{Sea Trout.}Divers bring up{Clams}(Scallops) while{Whelks (Winkles) and{Cockles}are collected and eaten as delicacies.{Spoots}(Razor Fish)are popular locally, and are dug from the sand at low tide. {Tangles}(thick stems of a sea growing plant containing iodine) are still sometimes gathered. When dried they are sold to Algenate Industries.
